required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Effect of Physical Therapy Exercise Program and Low-Level Laser Therapy on the Treatment of Cervicogenic Somatosensory Tinnitus
clinical_study.official_title: Effect of Adding Supervised Physical Therapy Exercise Program to Low Level Laser Therapy on the Treatment of Cervicogenic Somatosensory Tinnitus

brief_summary.textblock: To determine the effectiveness of adding a physical therapy exercise program to low-level laser therapy on the treatment of chronic tinnitus treatment

primary_outcome.description: Evaluate tinnitus severity before and after treatment for both groups

arm_group.description: Subjects in this group received low-level laser therapy
Subjects in this group received additional planned exercise therapy program

intervention.intervention_name: Exercise Therapy program added to laser therapy
intervention.description: a supervised physical therapy exercise program for the neck muscles in the form of manual mobilizations for sternocleidomastoid muscle and upper fibers of trapezius in addition to myofascial trigger point release

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Age ranged from 45 to 55 years old both sex
- Unilateral tinnitus
- Stable tinnitus for at least 3 months
- suffering from severe chronic non-fluctuating subjective cervicogenic somatic tinnitus (CST)
Exclusion Criteria:
- tinnitus with clear ontological etiologies as perforation of the tympanic membrane
- external otitis media
- conductive hearing loss
- patients with a traumatic cervical spine injury, tumors
- Any history of exposure to ototoxic drugs/substances
- psychotic disorders with auditory hallucination

responsible_party.investigator_title: assistant professor of physical therapy for surgery
